The source has zs\u00a0=\u00a02.737\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.003, as evaluated on Ly\u03b1 and C\u2009iv. The lens galaxy spectrum, with a shape that is well distinguishable from those of the quasar images, is traced in red for the reader's convenience.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2950fig2.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/106495633/stx2950fig2.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2950fig2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"106495633\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/474/3/10.1093_mnras_stx2950/1/stx2950fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466300&Signature=x7xSaMxFo9Hkii~DnHe572uPhzexdXIbFGaD8iU1Uf0p~pE18Cw233fCTiTC4sSvRaL5-cQ8TbQG1wIoB~NfbL2-esAg9FoKl1KRHkWIvQEtjT03cKBYoEeW3W7WHTjMCO71WmQ~rh2WITcSG0W4V4JbmY0YsJoFun3tgXOpgnaXuJ99C3yxdvcFfSaaF4HR7DAAzCu0N82Lw8biuOrD0RvuI1gy8M7OM-jskla6rUw77gjuGjMTZK93AEcOjzlvdG4x2G3Gw0jMAd6Acte1P0Oa3SZhc~dYpuQH~9LuXs7AQn2vraRTI7kpdT-4xpuypGTrzGVehCM2viAKYm5qYw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=106495633&ar=4644836&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2950fig2.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">ALFOSC discovery spectra. North\u2013south (top panel) and east\u2013west spectra (<em>centre</em>), and flux-ratios of spectra in north\u2013south slit (bottom panel). Image C leaks in the north\u2013south slit and is significantly reddened (green line), whereas images A,B have almost indistinguishable spectra (black line). The source has <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.737\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.003, as evaluated on Ly\u03b1 and C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iv</span>. The lens galaxy spectrum, with a shape that is well distinguishable from those of the quasar images, is traced in red for the reader's convenience.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=106495634 id=\"106495634\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 NOT imaging</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Follow-up imaging data with good seeing (\u22480.6\u2009arcsec full width at half-maximum at Zenith) were obtained with ALFOSC in <em>B, V, R, i</em> bands, using multiple 60\u2009s exposures per band. Standard <span class=\"small-caps\">Python</span> routines were used for bias subtraction, flat-fielding and coadding. The median coadds and colour-composites are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, where Ly\u2009\u03b1 from the quasar images dominates in <em>B</em>band and the lens brightens up in redder bands.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The relative displacements are obtained both from imaging and spectroscopic data. Individual traces in the spectra are well described by Gaussians in the spatial direction, whose run with wavelength can be modelled with uncertainties as low as 0.125\u2009pixels = 25\u2009mas. Uncertainties from imaging-only data, though nominally smaller, are dominated by systematics from different noise realizations. Residuals between imaging data and model, mostly due to faint features and PSF mismatch, are within the noise level.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> gives the positions of the four images (A,B,C,D) and deflector (G), relative to image A, and <em>BVRi</em> magnitudes. Images C and D are substantially reddened, and blending between D and G is significant in <em>B</em> band.</p>                        <a id=\"106495638\" scrollto-destination=\"106495638\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Image positions, <em>BVRi</em> magnitudes, and model-predicted values of (point-source) magnifications and time-delays. The nominal errors on some magnitudes would be smaller than quoted, but are limited by the accuracy of the ALFOSC zero-points and observing sky conditions.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Image<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b4<em>x</em>(arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>\u03b4<em>y</em>(arcsec)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>B</em><span high\u00a0</td><td>1.90\u2009arcsec\u00a0</td><td>0.58\u00a0</td><td>0.25[rad]\u00a0</td><td>1.22[rad]\u00a0</td><td>0.13\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/106495639\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=106495640 id=\"106495640\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Keck-ESI follow-up</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">ESI spectra of G were taken in echellette mode, with 1.0\u2009arcsec slit-width oriented east\u2013west and resolution <em>R</em>\u00a0=\u00a04900, roughly constant to within 10\u2009per\u2009cent over the whole spectral range. The total integration time was 45\u2009min split into three exposures of 900 seconds each. Bias and dark subtraction, flat-field correction, sky subtraction, and spectral extraction are performed directly by <span class=\"small-caps\">ESIREdux</span>. The combined 1D spectrum of G and D, shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, has distinctive absorption features at <em>z</em><sub>l</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.407\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.002 (Ca HK, <em>G</em> band, H\u2009\u03b2, Mg\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>/Fe complex, Na D), which we associate with the lens galaxy. The same features could be seen in the ALFOSC discovery spectra, although not as clearly.</p>                        <a id=\"106495642\" scrollto-destination=\"106495642\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/474/3/10.1093_mnras_stx2950/1/m_stx2950fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466300&amp;Signature=TADMXIRq7zzlvdq8520zsmFfTsWSa3iE25bkiXaUM8qwUK8q8H4unsA8XKFlIDY2uqbxPCYlL4bsdngD3~S1HDF62PV9paNGmmLwdXSdn7Kt76XVBBsivtzO8zSop0c6L8WAoLv7E6uBHqW7iWaI4Splgsh3EafHK7vch5hMLH-u3wYjbwjt7vWKJzysePz2ICBFhKFDPcjaEW5CrVAkDJ7Ma81yNDrufVMdRXcCDTGgykzEPU32N5q-GUyyGD9Uq-FqfWYShy2OAbboBbLqaEOluImYRjMVfixQYhgXYRFIWvCmk04lDn5pHpYGvBOI-AuKvJOAh-NlCG58ZLIdZQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"ESI follow-up spectra, with prominent absorption features at zl\u00a0=\u00a00.407\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.002, which we associate with G. Red dashed lines: Ca HK, G-band \u03bb4304, Mg i, Na D absorption at zl. Blue solid lines: quasar emission at zs. The Ca HK complex is visible, albeit at lower signal-to-noise ratio, also in the ALFOSC spectra.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2950fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/106495642/stx2950fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2950fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"106495642\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/474/3/10.1093_mnras_stx2950/1/stx2950fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466300&Signature=HxouL0IuM~gcYUF5I9Mp7e-08CxjsUmX-q--lI-lhu6Dolo0zgC3K5OZA7cLevwGUpuu5O1zcguNpcNUN1Cu37ypDTFDF7SWeSb0k0G-SHFZSWPI771AxRbLiKBC9gG4cUHNKFN9S531VinI1EwdNamTuJLisyM8D-TyilA32ud4WwiZjCdeTAO-nDzyZX~33C4OJukp3aFHY1tQdT9TioKlDaJ631vprBghw9pmV5C-7~MZYFjm98Ukcg3FEbkNznjbNKX1pC0MLF1I4nAwU8qJHpEH~4nCVcoA~SL3P5T5hw0fd6vtGok~~8D8DlFAsDfDDkjvreMWVfoRTcL3SA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=106495642&ar=4644836&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2950fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">ESI follow-up spectra, with prominent absorption features at <em>z</em><sub>l</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.407\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.002, which we associate with G. <em>Red dashed</em> lines: Ca HK, <em>G</em>-band \u03bb4304, Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>, Na D absorption at <em>z</em><sub>l</sub>. <em>Blue solid</em> lines: quasar emission at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>. The Ca HK complex is visible, albeit at lower signal-to-noise ratio, also in the ALFOSC spectra.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/474/3/10.1093_mnras_stx2950/1/m_stx2950fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466300&amp;Signature=TADMXIRq7zzlvdq8520zsmFfTsWSa3iE25bkiXaUM8qwUK8q8H4unsA8XKFlIDY2uqbxPCYlL4bsdngD3~S1HDF62PV9paNGmmLwdXSdn7Kt76XVBBsivtzO8zSop0c6L8WAoLv7E6uBHqW7iWaI4Splgsh3EafHK7vch5hMLH-u3wYjbwjt7vWKJzysePz2ICBFhKFDPcjaEW5CrVAkDJ7Ma81yNDrufVMdRXcCDTGgykzEPU32N5q-GUyyGD9Uq-FqfWYShy2OAbboBbLqaEOluImYRjMVfixQYhgXYRFIWvCmk04lDn5pHpYGvBOI-AuKvJOAh-NlCG58ZLIdZQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"ESI follow-up spectra, with prominent absorption features at zl\u00a0=\u00a00.407\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.002, which we associate with G. Red dashed lines: Ca HK, G-band \u03bb4304, Mg i, Na D absorption at zl. Blue solid lines: quasar emission at zs. The Ca HK complex is visible, albeit at lower signal-to-noise ratio, also in the ALFOSC spectra.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2950fig3.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/106495642/stx2950fig3.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2950fig3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"106495642\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/474/3/10.1093_mnras_stx2950/1/stx2950fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466300&Signature=HxouL0IuM~gcYUF5I9Mp7e-08CxjsUmX-q--lI-lhu6Dolo0zgC3K5OZA7cLevwGUpuu5O1zcguNpcNUN1Cu37ypDTFDF7SWeSb0k0G-SHFZSWPI771AxRbLiKBC9gG4cUHNKFN9S531VinI1EwdNamTuJLisyM8D-TyilA32ud4WwiZjCdeTAO-nDzyZX~33C4OJukp3aFHY1tQdT9TioKlDaJ631vprBghw9pmV5C-7~MZYFjm98Ukcg3FEbkNznjbNKX1pC0MLF1I4nAwU8qJHpEH~4nCVcoA~SL3P5T5hw0fd6vtGok~~8D8DlFAsDfDDkjvreMWVfoRTcL3SA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=106495642&ar=4644836&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2950fig3.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">ESI follow-up spectra, with prominent absorption features at <em>z</em><sub>l</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.407\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.002, which we associate with G. <em>Red dashed</em> lines: Ca HK, <em>G</em>-band \u03bb4304, Mg <span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>, Na D absorption at <em>z</em><sub>l</sub>. <em>Blue solid</em> lines: quasar emission at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>. The Ca HK complex is visible, albeit at lower signal-to-noise ratio, also in the ALFOSC spectra.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We measured the lens velocity dispersion by fitting a Gaussian profile to the Ca K line, yielding \u03c3<sub>los</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0(216\u00a0\u00b1\u00a055)\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>. This corresponds to the integrated velocity dispersion within a 1\u2009arcsec wide spectroscopic aperture centred on the lens galaxy G, which is partly blended with image D due to \u223c1\u2009arcsec seeing.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=106495644 id=\"106495644\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 LENS MODELS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">From the relative displacements in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, we fit a simple lens model to obtain the enclosed (2D) mass and predicted magnifications and time-delays. We do a conjugate-point analysis using <span class=\"small-caps\">Glee</span> (Suyu &amp; Halkola\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), adopting 25\u2009mas uncertainties on the positions of A,B,C and G, and 50 mas uncertainties on the position of image D. We do not fit to the flux-ratios, as, in general, they can be significantly affected by differential extinction, microlensing, and time-delays, and we can expect this to happen also in this case from the ratio of spectra shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The surface density of the lens is described by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\kappa (x,y)=\\frac{\\Sigma (x,y)}{\\Sigma _{\\rm cr}} =\\frac{b}{2\\sqrt{X^{2}/(1+e)^{2}\\, +Y^{2}/(1-e)^{2}}}\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>(Kassiola &amp; Kovner\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1993</a>), along the principal axes of G, where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Sigma _{\\rm cr}=\\mathrm{c}^{2}D_{s}/(4\\pi G\\, D_{\\text{l}}D_{\\text{ls}})$|</span> factors the dependence on angular-diameter distances. The coordinates (<em>X, Y</em>) are rotated from the standard coordinates (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\delta x=-\\cos (\\rm {\\text{Dec}.})\\delta \\rm {{\\rm RA}},$|</span><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\delta y=\\delta \\rm {\\text{Dec}.}$|\u2060</span>) by an angle \u03d5<sub>l</sub>. The Einstein radius is defined as the geometric mean of the major and minor axes of the critical curve, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\theta _{\\rm E}=2b\\sqrt{q}/(1+q).$|</span> We include external shear, with amplitude \u03b3<sub>s</sub> and angle \u03d5<sub>s</sub>, and allow all parameters to vary freely, including the lens flattening <em>q</em>\u00a0=\u00a0(1\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>e</em>)/(1\u00a0+\u00a0<em>e</em>) and position angle \u03d5<sub>l</sub>. The models then have seven parameters (<em>b</em>, \u03d5<sub>l</sub>, <em>q</em>, \u03d5<sub>s</sub>, \u03b3<sub>s</sub>, and the source position) and eight constraints with uncertainties (the relative displacements of the four image positions). The lens centre, nominally adding two free parameters, is already well constrained within (at most) 0.05\u2009arcsec by the ALFOSC cutout models (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>).</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The results are summarized in Tables 1and 2, and Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>. The Einstein radius is robustly determined to \u03b8<sub>E</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0(1.80\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10)\u2009arcsec, very close to half the A\u2013B separation and independent of other inferred quantities. Flux-ratios from the best-fitting model are comparable to those measured in <em>i</em> band, accounting for differential extinction whose existence in lensing is well established (e.g. Falco et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Mediavilla et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; El\u00edasd\u00f3ttir et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Agnello et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). The predicted delays <em>t<sub>D</sub></em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>t<sub>A</sub></em>\u00a0&gt;\u00a0100\u2009d, <em>t<sub>C</sub></em>\u00a0\u2212\u00a0<em>t<sub>A</sub></em> \u2248 25\u2009d can be accurately measured in one or two seasons of high-cadence monitoring.</p>                        <a id=\"106495648\" scrollto-destination=\"106495648\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/474/3/10.1093_mnras_stx2950/1/m_stx2950fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611466300&amp;Signature=Nt29AM7OoS8oFPanUi-eqc9MDSm5DVEojZmnL0C~02svQaii0gEC8Pg6AQgvi-j-756gX58nhpBSJP5kMHgWd6kY3s1tVFqh3ouT1I5H6wLDmXpOcIBzG6QW93a6SLb5~8TblH5yqpDP9ASR-aOGYzBdaffqrXIyOhyfFcoC0dladXJkWhAlOAGvZPEYoo~cmg7k8FSYfKHEnx9a9raU-0ve5aqzHhHS6JikYivGctFhinGUHTAPKI1L5XR3cvJvIe47P8Klc8GiELE14C-NNW3Vuf23sWoS0glzjfWqq4VqxMEO8~61Ge-s6gQQS5dmhaX3rmzeuj5-O-LTuYP5VA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Lens model results: observed image positions (open squares), model-predicted images (open circles) and lens centre (blue point), inferred source position (fuchsia bullet), critical curve (blue), and radial and astroid caustics (red). The position of image D is slightly biased, due to blending with G, but is recovered within the adopted uncertainties. The axes mark $\\theta _{1}=-\\cos (\\mathrm{\\text{Dec}.})\\delta \\mathrm{{\\rm RA}}$ and $\\theta _{2}=\\delta \\mathrm{{\\rm Dec.}}$\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2950fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/106495648/stx2950fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2950fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"106495648\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/474/3/10.1093_mnras_stx2950/1/stx2950fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611466300&Signature=1TLLKe0pswUuCDuQO45z8wAdk8agQF9Nr7Vbv4trur4F20p3VkZ7rSwfyzknMWnyJh5WBgocBvq8lCOcCp61Rt68v0HcAvLfN9A~fMWGz0JgZnABfTZx7jGOmkh-Y30i2jfVRrJcr9M9fy2OJJSfZB1PJhVsGJpkm-bjZL3mQ~7oHFW8lqQVNlRu~I9gmoAZvQQa-LsCPd7vEkd9BUpZzwgCeBsbrUKG0MUF283S2nuKXwb17p-WDBAGZInjv5li44dffN-n8MHlXR7HJEWdLgwltnfZYCTjMeFKkAVb356VzEm2MDFZXlIhfwsiKD6IFKkdU-1tPVVlqRc8Scu9Tw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=106495648&ar=4644836&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2950fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lens model results: observed image positions (open squares), model-predicted images (open circles) and lens centre (blue point), inferred source position (fuchsia bullet), critical curve (blue), and radial and astroid caustics (red). The position of image D is slightly biased, due to blending with G, but is recovered within the adopted uncertainties. The axes mark <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\theta _{1}=-\\cos (\\mathrm{\\text{Dec}.})\\delta \\mathrm{{\\rm RA}}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\theta _{2}=\\delta \\mathrm{{\\rm Dec.}}$|</span></p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/474/3/10.1093_mnras_stx2950/1/m_stx2950fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611466300&amp;Signature=Nt29AM7OoS8oFPanUi-eqc9MDSm5DVEojZmnL0C~02svQaii0gEC8Pg6AQgvi-j-756gX58nhpBSJP5kMHgWd6kY3s1tVFqh3ouT1I5H6wLDmXpOcIBzG6QW93a6SLb5~8TblH5yqpDP9ASR-aOGYzBdaffqrXIyOhyfFcoC0dladXJkWhAlOAGvZPEYoo~cmg7k8FSYfKHEnx9a9raU-0ve5aqzHhHS6JikYivGctFhinGUHTAPKI1L5XR3cvJvIe47P8Klc8GiELE14C-NNW3Vuf23sWoS0glzjfWqq4VqxMEO8~61Ge-s6gQQS5dmhaX3rmzeuj5-O-LTuYP5VA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Lens model results: observed image positions (open squares), model-predicted images (open circles) and lens centre (blue point), inferred source position (fuchsia bullet), critical curve (blue), and radial and astroid caustics (red). The position of image D is slightly biased, due to blending with G, but is recovered within the adopted uncertainties. The axes mark $\\theta _{1}=-\\cos (\\mathrm{\\text{Dec}.})\\delta \\mathrm{{\\rm RA}}$ and $\\theta _{2}=\\delta \\mathrm{{\\rm Dec.}}$\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2950fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/106495648/stx2950fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2950fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"106495648\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/474/3/10.1093_mnras_stx2950/1/stx2950fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611466300&Signature=1TLLKe0pswUuCDuQO45z8wAdk8agQF9Nr7Vbv4trur4F20p3VkZ7rSwfyzknMWnyJh5WBgocBvq8lCOcCp61Rt68v0HcAvLfN9A~fMWGz0JgZnABfTZx7jGOmkh-Y30i2jfVRrJcr9M9fy2OJJSfZB1PJhVsGJpkm-bjZL3mQ~7oHFW8lqQVNlRu~I9gmoAZvQQa-LsCPd7vEkd9BUpZzwgCeBsbrUKG0MUF283S2nuKXwb17p-WDBAGZInjv5li44dffN-n8MHlXR7HJEWdLgwltnfZYCTjMeFKkAVb356VzEm2MDFZXlIhfwsiKD6IFKkdU-1tPVVlqRc8Scu9Tw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=106495648&ar=4644836&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2950fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lens model results: observed image positions (open squares), model-predicted images (open circles) and lens centre (blue point), inferred source position (fuchsia bullet), critical curve (blue), and radial and astroid caustics (red). The position of image D is slightly biased, due to blending with G, but is recovered within the adopted uncertainties. The axes mark <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\theta _{1}=-\\cos (\\mathrm{\\text{Dec}.})\\delta \\mathrm{{\\rm RA}}$|</span> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\theta _{2}=\\delta \\mathrm{{\\rm Dec.}}$|</span></p></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Monopole\u2013quadrupole degeneracies (e.g. Kochanek\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) are present, in particular, <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray}\r\n\\nonumber \\gamma _{\\rm s} &amp; \\approx &amp; 0.10+0.35(q-0.5),\\\\\r\n\\nonumber \\phi _{\\rm s} &amp; \\approx &amp; 1.1-1.5(b-2.5),\\\\\r\n\\gamma _{\\rm s} &amp; \\approx &amp; 0.10+0.35(\\phi _{l}-0.18),\r\n\\end{eqnarray} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>for this system. These may be broken with: observations of the line-of-sight environment, to characterize external contributions to the deflections; and higher resolution imaging, of both the lensed quasar host and of G, to disentangle shear and lens flattening. Significant quadrupole, in the form of external shear or ellipticity, is not unexpected in quasar lenses (Keeton, Kochanek &amp; Seljak\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>; Holder &amp; Schechter\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), and, in fact, multipole contributions can, in general, be enough to appreciably affect flux ratios (Xu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Hsueh et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Gilman et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>)</div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The velocity dispersion \u03c3 of stars in the lens is a useful observable that can be estimated from the lens model itself. A direct measurement of \u03c3 and its comparison with predictions from lensing can be used to measure cosmological distances and to constrain the dark matter density profile of the lens (Treu &amp; Koopmans\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Grillo, Lombardi &amp; Bertin\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Paraficz &amp; Hjorth\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Jee et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). In the singular isothermal sphere (SIS) limit <em>q</em> \u2192 1, \u03c3 depends weakly on location<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn5\" data-open=\"fn5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">5</a></sup> and is well approximated by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\n\\sigma _{\\rm sis}^{2}=\\frac{\\mathrm{c}^{2}\\theta _{\\rm E}D_{\\text{s}}}{4\\pi D_{\\text{ls}}}\\ .\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div>With the above values, we then obtain \u03c3\u00a0=\u00a0(290\u00a0\u00b1\u00a08)\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>, as expected for massive ellipticals (Treu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>). A direct comparison between the estimate in equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ3\"></span><a href=\"#equ3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>) and direct measurements will need dynamical models that encompass asphericity and inclination effects (Barnab\u00e8 et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), as well as a more accurate measurement of \u03c3 from deeper spectra with a robust subtraction of the quasar contamination.</div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=106495651 id=\"106495651\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 DISCUSSION AND CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Lensed quasars are rare, and quadruply lensed quasars are even rarer. Assembling homogeneous sets of quasar lenses, with a selection function that can be well characterized and with the capability of discovering \u2018new\u2019 quads, is paramount to different lines of investigation (microlensing, substructure lensing, cosmography) that require samples of \u224840 lenses each, with suitable ancillary data. The advent of wide-field surveys helps overcome the rarity of these systems, provided lens searches can be performed on photometric data and recover systems to a good completeness level, spanning source redshifts <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0&gt;\u00a02, where most lenses are expected to lie.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have found a new, quadruply lensed quasar at RA = 14:33:22.8, Dec. = +60:07:14.5, via an outlier-selection procedure applied to the SDSS\u2013DR12 photometric footprint (detailed by Agnello\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Similar to other recent, wide-field photometric searches, this search did not rely on previous spectroscopic or UV excess information. This approach enables the discovery of systems with sources at higher redshifts than typically probed, and with appreciable differential reddening by the lens galaxy. This aspect is particularly relevant if, for example, microlensing or substructure studies are concerned, since one needs to ensure that the samples themselves are not biased against systems with significant departures from the simplest image and flux-ratio configurations.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Discovery NOT\u2013ALFOSC data confirmed this system as a lens with <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.737 and four images on a fold configuration. The lens redshift is <em>z</em><sub>l</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.407 from follow-up Keck-ESI spectroscopy, which together with the lens model results with \u03b8<sub>E</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0(1.80\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.10)\u2009arcsec predicts a velocity dispersion \u03c3\u00a0=\u00a0(290\u00a0\u00b1\u00a09)\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>. The velocity dispersion measured from ESI data, within a 1\u2009arcsec aperture in 1\u2009arcsec seeing conditions, is \u03c3<sub>los</sub>\u00a0=\u00a0(216\u00a0\u00b1\u00a055)\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>, but deeper data in better seeing are needed, to accurately correct for contamination by the quasar images (C,D) and model aperture effects. Saddle-point images C,D are significantly reddened by the lens galaxy, while the A/B flux ratios agree with predictions by the lens model within \u22480.1\u2009mag.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This lens is then relevant to multiple applications. Microlensing is evident in the differential magnification of lines and continua, and it can yield a determination of the stellar mass fraction in a galaxy at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> \u2248 0.4 if deeper spectroscopic data are obtained. The expected time-delays (Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>) can be measured accurately with high-cadence campaigns spanning one or two monitoring seasons, making this system an ideal lens for a cosmographic sample. With current data, significant monopole-quadrupole degeneracies arise in the lens model, but they can be broken with deeper and higher resolution follow-up. This, in turn, will reduce the systematic errors in the lens macro-model, with applications to the study of dark matter density profiles, time-delay cosmography, microlensing, and detection of substructure.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=106495656 id=\"106495656\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" >Acknowledgements</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">CG and MB acknowledge support by VILLUM FONDEN Young Investigator Programme through grant no. 10123. TJ acknowledges support provided by NASA through Program # <em>HST</em>-HF2-51359 through a grant from the Space Telescope Science Institute, which is operated by the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc., under NASA contract NAS 5-26555. TT acknowledges support by the Packard Foundation through a Packard Research Fellowship and by the National Science Foundation through grant AST-1450141. SHS gratefully acknowledges support from the Max Planck Society through the Max Planck Research Group.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The data presented here were obtained in part with ALFOSC, which is provided by the Instituto de Astrofisica de Andalucia (IAA) under a joint agreement with the University of Copenhagen and NOTSA. We thank R.T. Rasmussen and T. Pursimo for support at the NOT.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Some of the data presented herein were obtained at the W. M. Keck Observatory, which is operated as a scientific partnership among the California Institute of Technology, the University of California and the National Aeronautics, and Space Administration. The Observatory was made possible by the generous financial support of the W. M. Keck Foundation. The authors wish to recognize and acknowledge the very significant cultural role and reverence that the summit of Maunakea has always had within the indigenous Hawaiian community. We are most fortunate to have the opportunity to conduct observations from this mountain.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=106495660 id=\"106495660\" class=\"backfootnotegroup-title\" >Footnotes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The probability of finding a quasar strongly lensed by a cluster is 1\u20132 orders of magnitude smaller than that by a galaxy, with only a few of the first systems known (e.g. Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19a\" data-open=\"bib19a\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19b\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19b\" data-open=\"bib19b\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>).</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn2\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn2\" class=\"end-note-link\">2</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Here <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mathcal {L}_{\\text{star},i}$|</span> is the pipeline-estimated probability that an object is a single point-source; details on stellarity and model/psf magnitudes can be found in the SDSS schema browser.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn3\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn3\" class=\"end-note-link\">3</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The exact numbers depend on the pseudo-distance cuts chosen in this search, and visual-inspection. In this search, the final sample had 253 candidates and 38 known lenses/pairs.</p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn4\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn4\" class=\"end-note-link\">4</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">Available at <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www2.keck.hawaii.edu/inst/esi/ESIRedux/\" target=\"_blank\">http://www2.keck.hawaii.edu/inst/esi/ESIRedux/</a></p></div></span></div><div content-id=\"fn5\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn5\" class=\"end-note-link\">5</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">The details depend on the steepness of the starlight's profile and the orbital anisotropy (Barnab\u00e8 et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>).</p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=106495666 id=\"106495666\" class=\"backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list\"><div content-id=\"bib1\" data-legacy-id=\"bib1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib1\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib1\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Abazajian</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">K. class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1093%2Fmnras%2Fstx1650\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib7\" data-legacy-id=\"bib7\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib7\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib7\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib7\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Assef</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">R. J.</div></span> et al.\u00a0</span>, <div class=\"year\">2013</div>, <div class=\"source \">ApJ</div>, <div class=\"volume\">772</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">26</div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0004-637X/772/1/26\" target=\"_blank\">Crossref</a></div><div class=\"adsDoiReference\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/basic_connect?qsearch=10.1088%2F0004-637X%2F772%2F1%2F26\" target=\"_blank\">Search ADS</a></div><div class=\"xslopenurl empty-target\"><span class=\"inst-open-url-holders\" data-targetId=\"10.1088%2F0004-637X%2F772%2F1%2F26\"> </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div><div content-id=\"bib8\" data-legacy-id=\"bib8\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib8\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib8\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib8\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\">\r\n<span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Barnab\u00e8</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">M.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Czoske</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">O.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Koopmans</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">L. V. E.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Treu</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">T.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Bolton</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">A. S.</div></span></span>, <div class=\"year\">2011</div>, <div class=\"source \">MNRAS</div>, <div class=\"volume\">415</div>, <div class=\"fpage\">2215</div></p><!--citationLinks: case 1--><div class=\"widget-columns widget-col-1\">\r\n                    <div class=\"col\">\r\n\r\n<div class=\"widget-dynamic-entry\">\r\n    <input id=\"hfDoi\" name=\"hfDoi\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"10.1093/mnras/staa3878\" />\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n<a href=\"/mnras/advance-article/doi/10.1093/mnras/staa3878/6041709?searchresult=1\">\r\n        <div (function () {\r\n            var hfSiteUrl = document.getElementById('hfSiteURL');\r\n            var siteUrl = hfSiteUrl.value;\r\n            var subdomainIndex = siteUrl.indexOf('/');\r\n\r\n            hfSiteUrl.value = location.host + (subdomainIndex >= 0 ? siteUrl.substring(subdomainIndex) : '');\r\n        })();\r\n    </script>\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\"       });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleLinks widget-instance-OUP_Article_Links_Widget\">\n         \n class=\"dropdown-panel mobile-account-dropdown\">\r\n        <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n            <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                <a href=\"\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-signin dummy-link js-header-account-info-user-fullname\" id=\"header-account-info-user-fullname-mobile\">\r\n                    \r\nSign In                    <i class=\"mobile-nav-arrow icon-general_arrow-down\"></i>\r\n                </a>\r\n                <ul class=\"site-menu site-menu-lvl-1 individual-menu\">\r\n                    <li class=\"site-menu-item site-menu-lvl-0\">\r\n                        <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"nav-link mobile-account-institution dummy-link\">\r\n                            Eccles Health Sci                         <li class=\"dropdown-institution-item\">\r\n\r\nEccles Health Sci Lib-Serials\r\n                            </li>\r\n\r\n                        <li           <a href=\"/my-account/register?siteId=5326&amp;returnUrl=%2fmnras%2farticle%2f474%2f3%2f3391%2f4644836\" class=\"register nav-link\">Register</a>\r\n                </li>\r\n       <nav class=\"navbar-menu\">\r\n\r\n        </nav>\r\n            <div class=\"navbar-search-container js-navbar-search-container\">\r\n                <a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"navbar-search-close js_close-navsearch\">Close</a>\r\n                    <div class=\"navbar-search\">\r\n                        <div id=\"MicrositeSearch\" class=\"microsite-search\">\r\n                            <label for=\"navbar-search-filter\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search filter</label>\r\n                            <select class=\"navbar-search-filter\" id=\"navbar-search-filter\">\r\n                                                                    <optgroup label=\"Search within this journal\">\r\n label=\"Search beyond this journal\">\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Parent\" >All  RAS Journals</option>\r\n                                                <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Journals\" >All  Journals</option>\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                            </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=106495613 id=\"106495613\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We report the discovery of the quadruply lensed quasar SDSS J1433+6007 (RA = 14:33:22.8, Dec. = +60:07:13.44), mined in the SDSS DR12 photometric catalogues using a novel outlier-selection technique, without prior spectroscopic or ultraviolet excess information. Discovery data obtained at the Nordic Optical Telescope (La Palma) show nearly identical quasar spectra at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.737\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.003 and four quasar images in a fold configuration, one of which sits on a blue arc, with maximum separation 3.6\u2009arcsec. The deflector redshift is <em>z</em><sub>l</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.407\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.002, from Keck-ESI spectra. We describe the selection procedure, discovery and follow-up, image positions and <em>BVRi</em> magnitudes, and first results and forecasts from lens model fit to the relative image positions.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;methods: statistical&quot;\">methods: statistical</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;techniques: image processing&quot;\">techniques: image processing</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"catalogues\">catalogues</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=106495615 id=\"106495615\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Strong gravitational lensing by galaxies enables the study of distant sources and luminous and dark matter in galaxies over a range of redshifts (see e.g. Courbin, Saha &amp; Schechter\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>, for a review). When the source is a quasar, its multiple images give a wealth of information on: the source central engine and the stellar content of the lens, via microlensing by individual stars (Wambsganss\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; Kochanek\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Braibant et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>); substructure in the lens, via astrometric and flux-ratio \u2018anomalies\u2019 (Mao &amp; Schneider\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Dalal &amp; Kochanek\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Nierenberg et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Xu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Agnello et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>); quasars and their hosts at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> \u2248 2 (More et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Rusu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Agnello et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>); and from the time-delays between the light curves of different images, cosmological distances and tests of the Lambda cold dark matter concordance cosmology (Refsdal\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1964</a>; Kochanek\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Paraficz &amp; Hjorth\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">However, quasar lenses are rare, as they require the precise alignment of a distant source with (at least) a galaxy.<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> Oguri &amp; Marshall (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, hereafter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a>) estimate that \u22480.2 lensed quasars per square degree, brighter than <em>i</em>\u00a0=\u00a021, should be present in wide-field surveys, with a majority of doubly imaged quasars and \u2248 20\u2009per\u2009cent quadruples. Quasars are rare objects themselves and are less frequent beyond redshifts <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> \u2248 1.8 (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a>, M\u00e9nard et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), whereas quasar lenses should have source redshifts at <em>z</em> \u2248 2.5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.3, from <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a> models.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Since the first discovery of a lensed quasar (QSO 0957+561, Walsh, Carswell &amp; Weymann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52a\" data-open=\"bib52a\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1979</a>) in the radio, about 10<sup>2</sup> multiply imaged quasars have been discovered so far, with various methods in several optical and radio surveys. Some searches concentrated on bright quasars at redshift \u22651, such as the <em>HST</em> Snapshot Survey (Maoz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1992</a>), the Hamburg Bright Quasar Survey (Wisotzki et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>) and the Magellan survey (Wisotzki et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>, and references therein). The Jodrell Bank-VLA Astrometric Survey (JVAS; King et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24a\" data-open=\"bib24a\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>) and the Cosmic Lens All-Sky Survey (CLASS; Browne et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9a\" data-open=\"bib9a\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Myers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37a\" data-open=\"bib37a\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) targeted flat-spectrum radio-loud sources that could be resolved into multiple components in follow-up observations. The Sloan Quasar Lens Search (SQLS, Oguri et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) and its successor (BQLS, More et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) targeted objects with pre-existing quasar fibre-spectra, themselves based on ultraviolet excess (UVx) pre-selection. Optical and radio lens surveys are affected by different systematic effects, and it is thus fundamental to operate with samples of lenses selected from well-characterized populations of sources. The redshift distribution of sources is not the same across different searches, and can peak at lower redshifts than those predicted by <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">OM10</a>: in the SQLS, the source redhift distribution peaks at <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> \u2248 1.95 (respectively, <em>z</em><sub>s</sub> \u2248 1.5) for the statistically complete (respectively, full) sample.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Extensions of lens searches to higher completeness must rely solely on photometric pre-selection with limited UVx information. In view of current and upcoming wide-field surveys, diverse techniques have been developed to this aim. Searches tailored on the morphology of quasar lenses rely either on visual inspection of thousands of blue-near-red targets (Lin et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) or direct modelling of 10<sup>5</sup> image cutouts (Morgan et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Schechter et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). Data-mining techniques have been applied to catalogue magnitudes in the optical and infra-red, by selecting either large samples of quasar-like objects (Ostrovski et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) or objects resembling simulated lenses (Agnello et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015a</a>; Williams, Agnello &amp; Treu\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Lensed quasar selection via variability has been suggested (Kochanek et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), exploiting difference-imaging in multi-epoch surveys.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Here, we report on the discovery and follow-up of a quadruply lensed quasar, J1433+6007 (shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>), mined with a novel outlier-selection technique in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS, Abazajian et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>) DR12 footprint without spectroscopic or UVx information. The two brightest images are separated by \u22483.6\u2009arcsec, the source redshift from the discovery spectra is <em>z</em><sub>s</sub>\u00a0=\u00a02.737\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.003, and the lens redshift is <em>z</em><sub>l</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.407\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.002 from follow-up Keck-ESI spectroscopy. We describe the target/candidate selection procedure in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, the confirmation and follow-up of J1433+6007 in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>, and first lens models in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>. We conclude in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>. In what follows, SDSS magnitudes are in the AB system, WISE (Wright et\u00a0al.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>) magnitudes in the Vega system, and where necessary we adopt concordance cosmological parameters \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.7, \u03a9<sub>m</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.3, <em>H</em><sub>0</sub>\u00a0=\u00a070\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p>                        <a id=\"106495621\" scrollto-destination=\"106495621\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/474/3/10.1093_mnras_stx2950/1/m_stx2950fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466300&amp;Signature=3lKbUPy1LcKQ4JMdw0qzucpGxebW-TGKNEor0jZ1~XnEmH~wA2sT0J67FYxw~9HpSrqvDwxMu5T3WGyhG5pNtnNv5U72Q0ErJLZSul1Ml45cvybrB5U6AmMWw3gUCHChtX-V9C853Y6JWJbDam65YVG8ea8~tha9Yj~n7Sxc3~PIStljw0Cb1I6sx9EOf50J~plKPg2e2gIHLMro7p1VLHgQkk0mg-hA-BDWLZjsuI4FEJhFZnNuV72ZQor~MoOVOM20xNbpH7NEa2YG5GfUosCTMtqs9d90OJqbXsBXJkd09noje777X0u4JwUimpSH5QWocXOypcD1F7jsJyOxdg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"ALFOSC BVRi median coadds and \u2018false colour\u2019 RGB composites, North is up and East is to the left. In the RGB colour-composites, the horizontal white segment measures 1\u2009arcsec and the vertical segment spans the 3.6\u2009arcsec maximum image separation. A faint arc, barely visible in B band, emanates from the northern-most image. The colour-combination chosen here has red \u221d 0.3Rk, l, green \u221d 0.4Vk, l, blue \u221d 1.6Bk, l at pixel (k, l) in BVR, and red \u221d 0.3ik, l, green \u221d 0.4Rk, l, blue \u221d 1.6Vk, l at pixel (k, l) in VRi. This colour-code is chosen mostly for visual convenience, to mitigate the effects of sky noise, zero-point and site-specific extinction, making quasars appear \u2018blue\u2019 and early-type galaxies \u2018red\u2019: the quantitative information, consisting in object magnitudes, is given in Table\u00a01.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2950fig1.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/106495621/stx2950fig1.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2950fig1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"106495621\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/474/3/10.1093_mnras_stx2950/1/stx2950fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466300&Signature=zHerW9hBVO6Lp77FcFmQx0Y0aefJwjF3HCNM9KCn0Ayxz0QgjLu6cZWjHDlkRk50Tc9kj1Jic8jmcXMTuNJ5573R85V2x39tmw58CeVXw5couZxcFzMm-iIk-ARHXWRs5134SCGwxa05AqKs-eZ0V0LtTlXvRdlYAxvf~PCiQenqRl~AIpQlWhoGS0V6X1fxJzHfU7lFxrtbiRG2cAU1LH1yOH0hMvXmdFBpXbk~RANHSD-MF3Ma7flw58MxtBAGK0nKzo-v97PjuEQmElcl0DqTq2iyGXi3utr1xisC8fOmn2bg4kI5DOJoYMEnvvO5tR76PWBMueBIoSPb~JARJw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=106495621&ar=4644836&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stx2950fig1.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">ALFOSC <em>BVRi</em> median coadds and \u2018false colour\u2019 RGB composites, North is up and East is to the left.
